Explosions in Kremenchuk, Poltava Oblast

1 group impacted Kremenchuk/Svitlodovsk
3 more groups are flying further south to Oleksandriya, Kirovohrad Oblast.
1 group impacted Kremenchuk/Svitlodovsk  3 more groups are flying further south to Oleksandriya, Kirovohrad Oblast.
Approaching Oleksandriya
Flew southwest, away from the city, towards Kamianets

Correction: only 2 groups left.
Flying somewhat like this
Both groups are flying west now.
Both groups are flying west now.
Further to Vinnytsia Oblast
Missiles are flying somewhat low. Altitude: ~200 metres
Missiles are flying somewhat low. Altitude: ~200 metres
Both groups impacted Ladyzhyn Thermal Power Plant, Vinnytsia Oblast.
Unidentified missile to Zaporizhzhia City
Unidentified missile to Zaporizhzhia City
Just MLRS. No missiles.

Last night and this morning, another large-scale, combined Russian missile and drone attack was carried out on Ukraine.  Missiles launched:  ~30 Kh-101 cruise missiles from 9 Tu-95MS strategic bombers at their launch lines near the village of Uzmore, Saratov‚Ä¶

Additional missiles have since been used, so here is the updated missile map.
~8 more Kh-101s were launched from 1 Tu-160M strategic bomber at its launch lines in Vologda Oblast.
This brings the total number of Kh-101s launched to ~38, and the total number of missiles launched to ~59.
----------
The Ladyzhyn Thermal Power Plant, Vinnytsia Oblast (48.70562, 29.21877) was targeted by ~4 Kh-101s.
An unknown target (probably energy related) in/near Kremenchuk, Poltava Oblast was targeted by ~4 Kh-101s.

Consequences of Russian Geran-2 drone strikes on the 110 kV electrical substation in the village of Novi Petrivtsi, Kyiv Oblast.
Coordinates: 50.61845, 30.43824

A large fire can be seen burning at the "Zaporizhzhya" 750 kV electrical substation near the village of Vasylivka, Zaporizhzhia Oblast, after it was struck by at least 4 Tornado-S rockets.
Coordinates: 47.99958, 35.50939

A large fire can be seen burning at the "Zaporizhzhya" 750 kV electrical substation near the village of Vasylivka, Zaporizhzhia Oblast, after it was struck by at least 4 Tornado-S rockets.
Coordinates: 47.99958, 35.50939

A large fire is burning at the Kryvyi Rih Thermal Power Plant in the city of Zelenodolsk, Dnipropetrovsk Oblast, after it was struck by 5 Iskander-M ballistic missiles.
Coordinates: 47.54157, 33.6626

A fire is burning at the Kherson Thermal Power Plant after Russian artillery and FPV drones targeted it yesterday.
Widespread power outages are reported across Ukrainian-controlled Kherson Oblast.
Following the combined Russian missile and drone attack, several regions of Ukraine have implemented emergency power outages due to the significant damage sustained to energy infrastructure.

Russian forces have recaptured the village of Danylivka, Pokrovs'ke direction, Dnipropetrovsk Oblast.
Pre-war population: ~355.
Total land area: ~0.97 km¬≤.
The second battle for Danylivka lasted approximately 10 days.

2 Tu-95MS strategic bombers carried out launch maneuvers from Samara Oblast. We will find out if they were real or not in the next couple of hours.
I'm going to be now, though, so I will update you all tomorrow afternoon when I have time.

Strategic Shift: Ex-Saudi Intel Chief Says Israel Bigger Threat Than Iran
Saudi Arabia‚Äôs former intelligence chief said that Israel has become a greater threat to regional stability than Iran, signaling a shift in the strategic stance of the kingdom that began to emerge after the outbreak of the war in the Gaza Strip.
Asked which is a greater threat to regional stability during an onstage interview at the Milken Institute‚Äôs Middle East and Africa Summit in Abu Dhabi on December 5, Saudi Prince Turki Al Faisal responded, ‚ÄúFor the moment, definitely it is Israel.‚Äù
Prince Turki is a prominent member of the Saudi royal family. Thus, he remains influential in Riyadh even after leaving his position as intelligence chief.
Saudi Arabia has grown more hesitant about the prospect of normalizing with Israel as a result of the war in Gaza, which saw Israel expanding its operations across the region and even carrying out an unprecedented attack on Qatar right next to the kingdom in September.
Read more

Ukraine Admits Losses Following Massive Russian Group Strike (Videos)
Russia launched a massive group strike over the night of December 5 and 6, hitting targets in multiple regions in Ukraine, which acknowledged losses.
The Ukrainian Air Force said in a statement that the Russian military launched 653 drones and 51 missiles, including multiple hypersonic Kinzhals, during the large-scale strike. It went on to claim that its air defenses downed 585 drones and 30 missiles, but as usual Kiev later acknowledged losses indicating that the strike was successful.
The Russian Ministry of Defense later said that the ‚Äúmassive strike‚Äù was carried out in response to ‚Äú terrorist attacks launched by Ukraine against civilian facilities on the territory of Russia.‚Äù
Read more 
HERE

Syrian Army Received Anti-Drone Electronic Warfare Systems From Turkey (Video)
Turkey has supplied the new Syrian military with anti-drone electronic warfare systems in a new sign of growing defense cooperation between the neighboring countries.
The IHASAVAR, made by Turkish defense company Aselan, first made its appearance in Syria in a photo that emerged online on November 23. Later on December 6, the system appeared again, this time in a video taken during a military ceremony held to commemorate the first anniversary of the collapse of the regime of former Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.
In both cases it was reported that the system is in service with the 62nd Division, one of the largest formations of the Syrian military.
Read more 
HERE

Ukraine Is Losing Ground, Troops And Equipment All Around Pokrovsk (Videos)
On December 6, the Russian military expanded its control around the city of Pokrovsk and in the nearby besieged city of Myrnohrad, all while inflicting heavy losses on Kiev forces.
The Tsentr [Center] Group of Forces made substantial gains to the north of Pokrovsk, securing an area of 8.7 square kilometers. This tightened the siege on Myrnohrad, also known as Dimitrov, and increased pressure on Ukrainian troops fighting inside and around Rodynske to the north.
